questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: When is a dry or defective pilot bearing (ball type) noticeable?

options.A: When the clutch is engaged and the transmission is in gear.
options.B: When the clutch is disengaged and the transmission is in gear.
options.C: When the transmission is in neutral.
options.D: When the transmission is in low gear only.

explanations.A: Engaged clutch locks input shaft, pilot bearing doesn't rotate.
explanations.B: Disengaged clutch allows input shaft to spin while transmission stops, loading pilot bearing.
explanations.C: Neutral allows free rotation without load.
explanations.D: Gear selection doesn't specifically affect pilot bearing diagnosis.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What causes clutch slippage?

options.B: Worn friction disc, weak pressure plate springs, or oil contamination.
options.C: Too much free play in linkage.

explanations.A: Excessive free play prevents full engagement but doesn't cause slippage under load.
explanations.B: These conditions prevent adequate clamping force for power transmission.
explanations.C: Excessive free play affects engagement, not slippage during operation.
explanations.D: Proper adjustment prevents problems, doesn't cause them.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What indicates a worn clutch release bearing?

options.B: Noise when clutch pedal is depressed.

explanations.A: Worn bearings make noise, not silence.
explanations.B: Release bearing noise occurs when pedal is depressed and bearing contacts pressure plate.
explanations.D: Release bearing noise is separate from engine noise.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What causes hard clutch pedal operation?

options.B: Binding linkage, damaged cable, or failed assist mechanism.

explanations.A: Proper lubrication makes pedal operation easier.
explanations.B: Binding or resistance increases pedal effort required.
explanations.C: New clutches should operate normally with proper adjustment.
explanations.D: Correct adjustment ensures proper pedal feel.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of clutch pedal free play?

options.B: To ensure release bearing isn't constantly contacting pressure plate.

explanations.A: Free play prevents slippage by allowing full engagement.
explanations.B: Free play prevents bearing wear and allows complete clutch engagement.
explanations.C: Free play affects engagement point, not pedal effort.
explanations.D: Free play is essential for proper clutch operation.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What causes clutch chatter during engagement?

options.B: Glazed friction disc, oil contamination, or worn components.

explanations.B: These conditions cause uneven friction resulting in vibration.
explanations.C: Proper lubrication prevents binding but doesn't cause chatter.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: How is clutch adjustment verified?

options.B: By measuring free play at pedal and verifying release travel.

explanations.B: Measuring free play and travel ensures proper adjustment.
explanations.C: Adjustment is measurable at multiple points.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What indicates a failing clutch pressure plate?

options.B: Slippage under load, hard spots, or warped surface.

explanations.B: Pressure plate damage prevents proper clamping and causes performance issues.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What causes incomplete clutch disengagement (clutch drag)?

options.B: Insufficient free play, warped disc, or hydraulic system issues.

explanations.A: Excessive free play doesn't prevent disengagement.
explanations.B: These conditions prevent release bearing from fully separating clutch components.
explanations.D: New discs should disengage properly when adjusted correctly.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: How is clutch hydraulic system operation verified?

options.B: Check fluid level, bleed air, inspect for leaks, verify pedal feel.

explanations.A: Functional testing is required beyond visual inspection.
explanations.B: Comprehensive checks ensure proper hydraulic clutch operation.
explanations.D: Engine performance doesn't indicate clutch hydraulic condition.

questions.subtask: D-9.01 Diagnoses clutch systems
questions.question: What diagnostic test confirms clutch slippage?

options.A: Apply parking brake, engage high gear, release clutch - engine should stall if clutch holds.
options.B: Rev engine in neutral.

explanations.A: This test loads the clutch; slipping clutch allows engine to continue running.
explanations.B: Neutral testing doesn't load clutch.
explanations.C: Oil level doesn't directly test clutch holding ability.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What indicates a failing torque converter?

options.B: Overheating, shudder, slippage, or metal contamination in fluid.

explanations.B: These symptoms indicate internal damage or wear.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What is stall speed testing used for?

options.B: To evaluate torque converter and engine performance.

explanations.A: Stall testing is unrelated to radio systems.
explanations.B: Stall speed indicates converter efficiency and engine power output.
explanations.D: Stall testing is a valuable diagnostic procedure.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What causes high torque converter operating temperature?

options.B: Prolonged slippage, low fluid level, or inadequate cooling.

explanations.B: These conditions generate excessive heat through friction and inefficiency.
explanations.C: Cold weather typically reduces operating temperature.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What indicates lockup clutch failure in a torque converter?

options.B: Increased slippage at highway speeds, overheating, or shudder.

explanations.B: Failed lockup clutch causes continuous slippage and heat generation.
explanations.D: Engine temperature isn't directly affected by lockup clutch.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: How is transmission fluid condition evaluated?

options.B: By checking color, smell, and contamination presence.

explanations.A: Age alone doesn't indicate current condition.
explanations.B: Physical inspection reveals fluid degradation and contamination.
explanations.D: Mileage is a guide but actual condition must be checked.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What causes torque converter shudder?

options.B: Worn lockup clutch, contaminated fluid, or valve body issues.

explanations.B: These conditions cause uneven lockup clutch engagement.
explanations.D: While cold affects operation, it's not the primary shudder cause.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What is the function of a transmission retarder?

options.B: To provide engine braking and reduce service brake wear.

explanations.A: Retarders slow vehicles, not accelerate them.
explanations.B: Retarders create resistance to slow vehicle without using service brakes.
explanations.C: While they may affect economy, braking is the primary function.
explanations.D: Retarders are valuable safety and brake-saving devices.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: How is hydraulic retarder operation verified?

options.B: Activate retarder and verify braking effect, check for leaks, monitor temperature.

explanations.B: Operational testing confirms retarder provides braking force.
explanations.C: Retarder function is testable during operation.
explanations.D: Engine noise doesn't indicate retarder function.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What indicates contaminated transmission fluid?

options.B: Dark color, burnt smell, or presence of metal particles.

explanations.B: These signs indicate fluid degradation or component wear.
explanations.D: Proper viscosity alone doesn't indicate contamination.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What causes low stall speed readings?

options.B: Engine performance problems or torque converter issues.

explanations.A: High power would increase stall speed.
explanations.B: Low power output or converter slippage reduces stall speed.
explanations.C: Perfect operation produces normal stall speed.
explanations.D: Fluid level doesn't significantly affect stall speed.

questions.subtask: D-9.02 Diagnoses torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: How is torque converter lockup function diagnosed?

options.B: Monitor RPM drop when lockup engages or use scan tool to verify operation.

explanations.B: RPM change or scan data confirms lockup engagement.
explanations.D: Fluid color doesn't indicate lockup function.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What causes driveline vibration at specific speeds?

options.B: Worn U-joints, imbalanced driveshaft, or bent shaft.

explanations.B: These conditions create imbalance causing speed-related vibration.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: How are worn universal joints identified?

options.B: By checking for looseness, roughness, or noise during rotation.

explanations.B: Physical inspection reveals bearing wear and play in U-joints.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What indicates a bent driveshaft?

options.B: Vibration, visible runout when rotated, or uneven wear patterns.

explanations.B: Bending causes measurable runout and operational symptoms.
explanations.D: Bent shafts create noise and vibration.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What causes clunking during acceleration or deceleration?

options.B: Worn U-joints, loose slip yoke, or differential backlash.

explanations.B: Excessive clearance in these components creates impact noise during torque changes.
explanations.C: Lubrication reduces noise but doesn't cause clunking.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: How is driveshaft balance verified?

options.B: Using electronic balancer or checking for vibration at various speeds.

explanations.A: Balance requires dynamic testing or equipment.
explanations.B: Balancer or road testing identifies imbalance issues.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What indicates worn center bearing support?

options.B: Vibration, noise, or visible wear in bearing or mount.

explanations.B: Bearing wear causes vibration and allows shaft misalignment.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What causes driveline angle problems?

options.B: Incorrect ride height, worn suspension, or improper shaft installation.

explanations.B: These conditions change working angles causing vibration and wear.
explanations.C: Tire size changes can affect angles but aren't the primary cause.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: How are slip yoke splines checked?

options.B: Inspect for wear, looseness, and proper lubrication.

explanations.B: Worn or dry splines cause noise and allow excessive movement.
explanations.D: Transmission operation doesn't directly indicate spline condition.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What diagnostic procedure identifies driveline phase issues?

options.A: Check that yokes on multi-piece shafts are in phase (aligned).
options.B: Random inspection.

explanations.A: Out-of-phase yokes cause severe vibration; they must be aligned.
explanations.B: Specific alignment checking is required.
explanations.D: Fluid level doesn't relate to driveline phase.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: What causes premature U-joint failure?

options.B: Excessive angles, lack of lubrication, or contamination.

explanations.B: These conditions accelerate bearing wear and cause failure.

questions.subtask: D-9.03 Diagnoses driveline systems
questions.question: How is constant velocity (CV) joint condition assessed?

options.B: Check for clicking noise during turns, inspect boots, and check for play.

explanations.B: These checks identify wear and contamination in CV joints.
explanations.C: CV joints wear and require inspection.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: Road-testing of a rebuilt powershift transmission indicates that the lock-up shift points occur too early. What is the problem?

options.A: Lock-up valve oil pressure is too low.
options.B: Lock-up valve linkage is out of adjustment.
options.C: Lock-up valve spring pressure is too low.
options.D: Lock-up valve spring pressure is too high.

explanations.A: Low pressure would delay, not advance, shift points.
explanations.B: Linkage affects engagement point but not shift timing directly.
explanations.C: Weak spring allows valve to shift at lower pressure, causing early shifts.
explanations.D: High spring pressure would delay shift points.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What will be the result of overfilling a power shift transmission?

options.B: No forced downshift.
options.C: Low shift points at full throttle.

explanations.B: Overfilling doesn't prevent downshifts.
explanations.D: Excess fluid causes aeration and heat buildup from churning.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What indicates worn transmission synchronizers?

options.B: Grinding noise during gear changes or difficult shifting.

explanations.A: Smooth shifting indicates good synchronizer condition.
explanations.B: Worn synchronizers cannot match shaft speeds, causing grinding.
explanations.C: Perfect operation indicates proper synchronizer function.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What causes transmission to jump out of gear?

options.B: Worn shift forks, detents, or synchronizers.

explanations.A: New transmissions stay in gear properly.
explanations.B: Worn components cannot maintain engagement under load.
explanations.D: Fluid cleanliness doesn't prevent jumping out of gear.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: How is transmission fluid leak location identified?

options.B: Clean area, add dye if needed, operate and inspect with UV light or visual inspection.

explanations.B: Cleaning and dye make leak source visible.
explanations.C: Leaks are locatable with proper procedures.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What indicates low transmission fluid level?

options.B: Slipping, delayed engagement, or overheating.

explanations.B: Insufficient fluid prevents proper hydraulic pressure and cooling.
explanations.D: Low fluid typically causes overheating, not cold operation.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What causes harsh automatic transmission shifts?

options.B: Worn clutches, incorrect fluid, or valve body issues.

explanations.A: Proper valve operation produces smooth shifts.
explanations.B: These conditions cause abrupt engagement and harsh shifts.
explanations.C: New fluid should improve shift quality.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: How is transfer case operation verified?

options.B: Test all range selections, check for noise, verify engagement indicators.

explanations.B: Complete testing ensures all transfer case functions work properly.
explanations.C: Transfer case function must be verified.
explanations.D: Engine performance doesn't indicate transfer case operation.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What indicates transmission clutch pack failure?

options.B: Slipping in specific gears, delayed engagement, or no power transfer.

explanations.A: Perfect operation indicates good clutch condition.
explanations.B: Worn clutches cannot hold torque in affected gear ranges.
explanations.C: Smooth operation suggests proper clutch function.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What diagnostic information does transmission line pressure provide?

options.B: Indicates pump condition, valve body function, and clutch/band application.

explanations.A: Line pressure is a key diagnostic parameter.
explanations.B: Pressure readings diagnose hydraulic system health and operation.
explanations.C: Pressure indicates current condition, not age.
explanations.D: Pressure readings are separate from fluid appearance.

questions.subtask: D-9.04 Diagnoses transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What causes transmission to overheat?

options.B: Heavy loads, low fluid, slipping clutches, or restricted cooler.

explanations.B: These conditions generate excess heat or prevent adequate cooling.
explanations.C: Cold weather typically reduces operating temperature.
explanations.D: New transmissions should maintain normal temperature.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What causes differential gear noise during turns?

options.B: Worn spider gears or side gears.

explanations.B: Spider gear wear creates noise when wheels turn at different speeds.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: How is excessive ring and pinion backlash diagnosed?

options.B: Using a dial indicator to measure gear movement.

explanations.B: Dial indicator accurately measures gear clearance.
explanations.C: Backlash is measurable with proper tools.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What indicates worn axle bearings?

options.B: Growling noise that changes with speed, wheel play, or heat.

explanations.B: Bearing wear creates characteristic noise and symptoms.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What causes differential fluid leaks?

options.B: Worn seals, damaged housing, or overfilling.

explanations.B: These conditions allow fluid to escape from the housing.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: How is ring and pinion gear wear pattern evaluated?

options.B: Apply marking compound and observe contact pattern on gear teeth.

explanations.B: Contact pattern shows gear mesh alignment and condition.
explanations.D: Age doesn't show current wear pattern.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What indicates a limited slip differential malfunction?

options.A: Even power distribution to both wheels.
options.B: One wheel spinning freely with no power to the other.

explanations.B: Failed limited slip acts like open differential, allowing one-wheel spin.
explanations.C: Proper turn operation indicates good condition.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What causes clunking from the differential during direction changes?

options.B: Excessive backlash or worn gears.

explanations.B: Excessive clearance creates impact noise during torque reversal.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: How is differential fluid condition checked?

options.B: Drain sample and check for metal particles, water, or discoloration.

explanations.B: Fluid analysis reveals contamination and component wear.
explanations.D: Mileage is a guide but actual condition must be checked.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What indicates incorrect ring and pinion gear setup?

options.B: Noise, incorrect contact pattern, or rapid wear.

explanations.B: Improper setup causes poor gear contact and premature failure.
explanations.D: Temperature doesn't primarily indicate setup quality.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: What causes axle shaft breakage?

options.B: Overloading, shock loads, or fatigue from stress concentration.

explanations.A: Lubrication prevents bearing wear but doesn't strengthen shafts.
explanations.B: Excessive loading or stress risers cause shaft failure.
explanations.C: Normal operation doesn't break properly sized shafts.
explanations.D: Maintenance prevents some issues but can't prevent overload.

questions.subtask: D-9.05 Diagnoses axle and differential systems
questions.question: How is locking differential operation verified?

options.B: Engage lock and verify both wheels receive power, check indicator light.

explanations.B: Operational test confirms lock engages and distributes power equally.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What indicates planetary final drive wear?

options.B: Noise, vibration, or metal in lubricant.

explanations.B: Gear wear creates noise and releases metal particles into oil.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: How is final drive oil level checked on tracked equipment?

options.B: Check level at fill plug with machine on level ground.

explanations.B: Oil should be at plug level when properly filled on level surface.
explanations.C: Track tension is separate from oil level.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What causes final drive overheating?

options.B: Low oil level, worn gears, or excessive loading.

explanations.B: These conditions increase friction and heat generation.
explanations.C: Cold weather typically reduces operating temperature.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What indicates worn final drive bearings?

options.B: Growling noise, excessive play, or heat.

explanations.B: Bearing wear creates characteristic symptoms requiring replacement.
explanations.C: Smooth rotation indicates good bearing condition.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: How is final drive seal leakage diagnosed?

options.B: Visual inspection for oil seepage around seals and on brake components.

explanations.A: Seals wear and leak over time.
explanations.B: Oil traces indicate seal failure requiring replacement.
explanations.C: Age doesn't indicate current seal condition.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What causes excessive final drive gear noise?

options.B: Worn teeth, improper mesh, or inadequate lubrication.

explanations.A: New gears should operate quietly after break-in.
explanations.B: These conditions create poor tooth contact and noise.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: How is planetary gear backlash measured?

options.B: Using dial indicator while rotating components.

explanations.B: Dial indicator accurately measures gear clearance.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What indicates contaminated final drive oil?

options.B: Dark color, metal particles, or milky appearance from water.

explanations.B: These signs indicate wear or contamination requiring service.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What causes final drive to lose power?

options.B: Broken gear teeth, worn gears, or bearing failure.

explanations.B: Damaged components cannot transmit torque effectively.
explanations.C: New components provide full power transfer.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: How is final drive brake contamination identified?

options.B: Oil on brake components indicates seal leakage into brake housing.

explanations.B: Oil presence indicates seal failure requiring immediate attention.

questions.subtask: D-9.06 Diagnoses final drive systems
questions.question: What diagnostic procedure identifies final drive component wear?

options.B: Measure backlash, check oil for metal, inspect gears and bearings.

explanations.B: Multiple checks identify wear and determine service needs.
explanations.C: Wear is diagnosable through systematic inspection.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: What is the correct procedure for clutch disc installation?

options.B: Use clutch alignment tool, ensure correct orientation, and torque pressure plate bolts.

explanations.A: Alignment tool ensures transmission installation is possible.
explanations.B: Proper alignment and orientation ensure successful installation.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: How should clutch pressure plate bolts be tightened?

options.A: All at once to maximum torque.
options.B: In a star pattern, gradually to specification to prevent warping.

explanations.B: Gradual, even tightening prevents distortion.
explanations.D: Proper torque is required for adequate clamping force.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: What must be checked before installing a replacement clutch?

options.B: Flywheel surface condition, pilot bearing, and release bearing.

explanations.B: Worn related components cause premature new clutch failure.
explanations.D: All clutch system components should be inspected.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: How should clutch hydraulic systems be bled?

options.B: Starting from master cylinder, bleed until fluid flows without air bubbles.

explanations.A: Air must be removed for proper operation.
explanations.B: Systematic bleeding removes air ensuring firm pedal feel.
explanations.C: Adding fluid doesn't remove trapped air.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: What preparation prevents clutch disc contamination?

options.B: Clean flywheel and pressure plate surfaces, handle disc by edges only.

explanations.B: Clean installation prevents contamination and ensures proper friction.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: How should clutch linkage be adjusted?

options.B: Set free play per manufacturer specifications and verify full disengagement.

explanations.B: Proper free play ensures complete engagement and release.
explanations.C: Zero free play causes bearing wear and incomplete engagement.
explanations.D: Excessive free play prevents full disengagement.

questions.subtask: D-10.01 Repairs clutch systems
questions.question: What must be verified after clutch replacement?

options.B: Proper pedal feel, engagement point, complete disengagement, and no slippage.

explanations.B: Comprehensive testing confirms successful clutch replacement.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What procedure applies when replacing a torque converter?

options.B: Pre-fill with transmission fluid, verify proper seating on pump, rotate to engage splines.

explanations.A: Dry installation risks pump damage at startup.
explanations.B: Pre-filling and proper engagement prevent damage during installation.
explanations.C: Forcing damages components and indicates improper engagement.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: How should transmission fluid be changed after converter replacement?

options.B: Replace all fluid, flush cooler lines, and check for contamination.

explanations.A: Old contaminated fluid damages new converter.
explanations.B: Complete fluid replacement removes contamination from converter failure.
explanations.C: Topping off leaves contamination in system.
explanations.D: Fluid must be changed with converter replacement.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What must be checked when servicing transmission coolers?

options.B: Clean externally, check for leaks between fluid and coolant, verify flow.

explanations.B: Proper cooler service prevents overheating and cross-contamination.
explanations.D: Functional testing is required beyond visual inspection.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: How should retarder systems be serviced?

options.B: Check fluid level, inspect for leaks, verify control operation, test braking effect.

explanations.B: Comprehensive service ensures retarder reliability and effectiveness.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What preparation prevents transmission contamination during converter replacement?

options.B: Cap all openings, use clean fluid, work in clean area.

explanations.B: Cleanliness prevents premature component failure.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: How should converter-to-flexplate bolts be installed?

options.B: Torque to specification in star pattern using thread locker if specified.

explanations.A: Proper torque is required to prevent loosening.
explanations.B: Correct torque and pattern prevent vibration and loosening.

questions.subtask: D-10.02 Repairs torque converters, fluid couplers and retarders
questions.question: What must be verified after torque converter installation?

options.B: Proper converter depth, flexplate runout, fluid level, and no leaks.

explanations.A: Verification prevents damage and ensures proper operation.
explanations.B: These checks ensure safe and proper converter function.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: How should universal joints be replaced?

options.B: Use press or removal tool, install with proper orientation and grease.

explanations.B: Proper tools and procedures ensure correct installation.
explanations.C: Lubrication is essential for U-joint life.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: What must be checked when installing driveshafts?

options.B: Proper phasing, U-joint angles, slip yoke engagement, and balance marks aligned.

explanations.A: Proper installation prevents vibration and failure.
explanations.B: These factors ensure smooth operation and component longevity.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: How should driveshaft balance weights be handled?

options.B: Mark position before removal and reinstall in same location.

explanations.B: Original balance must be maintained for vibration-free operation.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: What procedure applies when replacing center support bearings?

options.B: Press bearing onto shaft, install support, and verify alignment.

explanations.A: Proper alignment prevents vibration and premature wear.
explanations.B: Proper installation and alignment ensure bearing longevity.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: How should slip yoke splines be serviced?

options.B: Clean, inspect for wear, and lubricate with appropriate grease.

explanations.A: Dry splines wear rapidly and make noise.
explanations.B: Clean, lubricated splines prevent wear and binding.
explanations.C: Engine oil doesn't provide adequate protection.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: What must be torqued properly during driveline assembly?

options.B: U-joint straps, yoke nuts, and center bearing mounting bolts to specification.

explanations.A: Proper torque prevents loosening and failure.
explanations.B: Correct torque ensures secure assembly without damage.
explanations.C: Hand-tight is insufficient for rotating components.

questions.subtask: D-10.03 Repairs driveline systems
questions.question: How should CV joint boots be replaced?

options.B: Clean joint, install new boot with proper grease, and secure clamps.

explanations.A: Torn boots allow contamination and grease loss.
explanations.B: Proper boot replacement protects joint from contamination.
explanations.C: Grease is essential for joint lubrication.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What preparation is necessary before transmission disassembly?

options.B: Clean exterior, drain fluid, mark component positions, organize workspace.

explanations.A: Preparation prevents contamination and ensures correct reassembly.
explanations.B: Systematic preparation protects components and aids reassembly.
explanations.C: Dirty exterior contaminates internals during disassembly.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: How should transmission bearings be installed?

options.B: Use press or bearing driver, ensure proper clearances, and lubricate.

explanations.B: Proper tools and procedures ensure correct bearing installation.
explanations.C: Lubrication protects bearings during initial operation.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What must be set correctly during transmission assembly?

options.B: End play, bearing preload, gear mesh, and shift linkage.

explanations.B: These adjustments are critical for transmission longevity and performance.
explanations.D: Systematic assembly with proper measurements is essential.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: How should transmission case bolts be torqued?

options.B: In sequence per specifications to prevent case warping.

explanations.A: Proper torque is required for sealing and strength.
explanations.B: Sequential torquing prevents distortion and ensures even clamping.
explanations.C: Excessive torque warps cases and damages threads.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What procedure prevents contamination during transmission rebuild?

options.B: Clean all parts thoroughly, use lint-free cloths, work in clean environment.

explanations.B: Cleanliness is critical for transmission longevity.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: How should clutch packs be assembled?

options.B: Alternate friction and steel plates per specifications, check clearance.

explanations.A: Specific plate order and count are required.
explanations.B: Proper assembly ensures correct clutch capacity and operation.
explanations.C: Plates must be alternated for proper function.
explanations.D: Clutch pack assembly is critical and has specific procedures.

questions.subtask: D-10.04 Repairs transmission and transfer case systems
questions.question: What must be verified after transmission installation?

options.B: All gear selections, shift quality, no leaks, proper fluid level.

explanations.B: Complete functional testing verifies successful rebuild and installation.
explanations.C: Starting doesn't verify all transmission functions.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: How should ring and pinion gears be installed?

options.B: Set proper backlash, preload, and verify contact pattern with marking compound.

explanations.A: Precise setup is required for proper gear mesh.
explanations.B: Proper setup ensures quiet operation and gear longevity.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: What is the correct bearing preload adjustment procedure?

options.B: Set per manufacturer specifications using shims or adjusting nuts.

explanations.A: Proper preload is essential for bearing life.
explanations.B: Correct preload prevents bearing damage and noise.
explanations.C: Excessive preload causes premature bearing failure.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: How should differential side gears and spider gears be inspected?

options.B: Check for wear, scoring, proper backlash, and thrust washer condition.

explanations.B: Thorough inspection identifies wear requiring replacement.
explanations.C: Gear condition directly affects differential operation.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: What sealant application prevents differential leaks?

options.B: Thin, even bead on mating surfaces per specifications, avoiding bolt holes.

explanations.A: Excess sealant can block passages and cause leaks.
explanations.B: Proper application ensures sealing without contamination.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: How should axle shafts be installed?

options.B: Align splines, slide into position, install retaining hardware per specifications.

explanations.B: Careful installation prevents damage to seals and splines.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: What must be done after differential assembly?

options.B: Fill with proper fluid, check for leaks, verify gear pattern, road test.

explanations.B: Comprehensive checks confirm successful rebuild.

questions.subtask: D-10.05 Repairs axle and differential systems
questions.question: How should limited slip differential clutches be serviced?

options.B: Replace clutches and plates as sets, use proper friction modifier in fluid.

explanations.A: Worn clutches don't provide proper limited slip function.
explanations.B: Complete clutch replacement and proper fluid ensure correct operation.
explanations.D: Specific procedures ensure proper limited slip operation.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: How should planetary gear assemblies be serviced?

options.B: Inspect all gears and bearings, measure clearances, replace worn parts.

explanations.B: Thorough inspection and measurement ensure reliable operation.
explanations.C: Measurements are required for proper assessment.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: What procedure prevents final drive seal leakage?

options.B: Lubricate seal lips, use proper installation tool, verify shaft condition.

explanations.B: Proper installation technique ensures sealing and seal longevity.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: How should final drive bearings be set?

options.B: Set proper preload and end play per manufacturer specifications.

explanations.B: Correct settings ensure bearing life and quiet operation.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: What must be verified during final drive assembly?

options.B: Gear mesh, backlash, bearing preload, and seal installation.

explanations.B: These checks prevent premature failure and ensure proper function.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: How should final drive housings be prepared for assembly?

options.B: Clean thoroughly, inspect for cracks, prepare mating surfaces.

explanations.B: Clean, sound housings are essential for seal integrity and component protection.
explanations.C: Proper preparation prevents leaks and contamination.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: What break-in procedure applies to rebuilt final drives?

options.B: Light duty operation initially, monitor temperature, check for leaks.

explanations.A: Immediate full load risks damaging new components.
explanations.B: Gradual break-in allows components to mate properly.
explanations.D: Maximum load damages newly assembled components.

questions.subtask: D-10.06 Repairs final drive systems
questions.question: How should final drive oil be serviced after rebuild?

options.B: Fill to proper level, check after initial operation, change after break-in period.

explanations.A: Initial oil change removes break-in debris.
explanations.B: Proper oil service removes wear particles from break-in.
explanations.C: Correct oil type is critical for component protection.
explanations.D: Overfilling causes aeration and seal damage.
